name: Monthly Retro: March 2025
premise: March 2025 was a “platform maturation” month: ElizaOS pushed hard on a redesigned agent-management UI, runtime/transport upgrades (Bun + Socket.io), and a broader plugin ecosystem—while community pressure concentrated around reliability at the edges (social clients), configuration drift (clients vs plugins), and knowledge/RAG fragility under real-world loads.
summary: The council agrees March materially advanced ElizaOS toward a more usable, modular agent platform: the new UI made configuration and debugging visible, core runtime/transport changes improved performance, and plugin work (notably Ollama) expanded model optionality. However, the month also surfaced a recurring trust gap: developers are hitting silent failures and migration confusion (clients/plugins), and high-visibility integrations (Twitter/Telegram/Discord) remain brittle. The council’s strategic conclusion: April should be a “Reliability + DX Convergence” sprint—stabilize a blessed path, add hard release gates, and treat docs + migration tooling as product-critical infrastructure.

key_developments.summary: A full client UI redesign shipped, enabling streamlined agent setup with plugins and environment variables, plus tooling like env uploaders and visibility into agent memories.
Core messaging moved from WebSockets to Socket.io and the runtime moved from Node to Bun, improving realtime robustness and performance while introducing a new baseline for operational expectations.
Users can now view agent actions and runtime logs directly in the UI, reducing debugging time and making failures less opaque.
A dedicated Ollama plugin improved local-model workflows; community platform integrations (Discord/Telegram) were enhanced; CLI improvements reduced friction for plugin installation and monorepos.
Documentation versioning (stable vs alpha), plus blog/showcase/changelog/RSS updates, reduced some confusion—but gaps remain in migration narratives and integration guides.
Agent secret salting was added, tightening configuration security without adding major workflow overhead.
OOM and splitText safeguards, plus fact-retrieval improvements, addressed some failure modes; large-file ingestion and PDF reliability continue to trigger heap pressure and unstable embeddings.

recurring_themes.theme: Configuration Drift (clients vs plugins) and Migration Confusion
recurring_themes.frequency: Very high (constant throughout the month across issues + community questions)
recurring_themes.council_take: We changed the mental model faster than we changed the guardrails. Without a canonical migration path, Eliza feels “unstable” even when code is improving.

recurring_themes.theme: Reliability Debt Moving to the Edges (social clients, adapters, hosting)
recurring_themes.council_take: Core is improving, but builders judge us by the integrations that touch users. Silent failures and duplicate behaviors are trust-killers.

recurring_themes.theme: Knowledge/RAG Fragility at Real-World Scale (OOM, PDFs, large docs)
recurring_themes.frequency: High (repeated operational signals and GitHub issues)
recurring_themes.council_take: RAG can’t be treated as “best-effort” if we want durable agents. We need bounded memory behavior and deterministic ingestion outcomes.

recurring_themes.theme: Documentation as Product Infrastructure (not an afterthought)
recurring_themes.frequency: Medium-high (docs versioning helped; broken links + recurring questions persisted)
recurring_themes.council_take: Docs are part of runtime reliability. If devs can’t successfully install, configure, and deploy, no amount of features matters.

recurring_themes.theme: Public Trust Signals Blocked by External Dependencies (web, X account, governance bottlenecks)
recurring_themes.frequency: Medium (less frequent than code issues, but high impact on perception)
recurring_themes.council_take: These are not “marketing chores.” Broken web presence and suspended accounts reduce ecosystem credibility and slow adoption.

wins: Shipped a redesigned agent-management UI that materially improves configuration and debugging workflows.
Improved observability by surfacing agent actions and runtime logs in the UI—reducing “black box” failure modes.
Advanced platform performance/reliability with Socket.io migration and Bun runtime adoption.
Expanded local-model support via the Ollama plugin, strengthening the open/composable model strategy.
Implemented secret salting, improving baseline security hygiene.
Docs improvements (versioning + new content surfaces) showed real progress toward “Taming Information.”
challenges: Developer confusion and broken setups stemming from shifting conventions (clients vs plugins) and insufficient migration tooling.
Recurring RAG ingestion failures and heap OOM under large documents/PDFs; reliability remains inconsistent beyond small demos.
Social client reliability issues (Twitter auth/config, Telegram silent init, Discord behavior mismatch) undermining trust-through-shipping.
Operational trust issues from broken public surfaces (e.g., eliza.gg) and external governance/account bottlenecks.
Regression risk remains: rapid shipping without strict release gates increases the chance of repeated break/fix cycles.

proposed_focus.area: DX Convergence: One Canonical Configuration + Migration Path
proposed_focus.rationale: The fastest route to regained developer trust is eliminating configuration ambiguity. March proved we can ship big changes; April must make them safe, learnable, and hard to misconfigure.
proposed_focus.success_metric: Reduce “install/config confusion” issues by 50% month-over-month; achieve >85% successful first-run setup (measured via opt-in CLI telemetry or installation survey); publish a single canonical migration doc and enforce it via CLI lint/check.

proposed_focus.area: Reliability Gates: Release Discipline + Observability Baseline
proposed_focus.rationale: We’re improving internals, but regressions keep leaking. Add automated checks that convert reliability into a measurable contract.
proposed_focus.success_metric: Introduce a release checklist with required soak tests; add integration smoke tests for blessed clients; target a 30% drop in runtime crash reports and “silent failure” complaints.

proposed_focus.area: RAG/Knowledge Hardening: Bounded Memory + Deterministic Ingestion
proposed_focus.rationale: Agents aren’t durable without durable memory/knowledge. OOM and large-file failures are gating real deployments.
proposed_focus.success_metric: Knowledge ingestion success rate >95% on a standard corpus suite (PDF + large markdown + multi-file folder); no single-file ingestion should exceed a configured memory/time budget; publish recommended ingestion limits and defaults.

proposed_focus.area: Blessed Integrations: Narrow, Guaranteed Social Surface (Twitter/Telegram/Discord)
proposed_focus.rationale: Builders judge us by what users see. Pick a small set of “gold path” integrations and make them boringly reliable before expanding breadth.
proposed_focus.success_metric: For each blessed client: documented setup in <15 minutes; error messages surfaced in UI; duplicate-post rate <1%; successful auth/connect rate >90% across fresh installs.

proposed_focus.area: Trust Surfaces: Fix the Web + Governance/Identity Bottlenecks
proposed_focus.rationale: Broken web presence and stalled identity changes create a perception of instability that negates shipping wins.
proposed_focus.success_metric: Restore/redirect eliza.gg to a maintained landing/docs hub; publish a single “official links” registry; weekly status note on external blockers until resolved.

north_star_assessment.suggested_updates: No change to the North Star mission, but add an explicit operational clause to “most reliable”: define reliability as measurable (crash-free sessions, integration success rates, deterministic RAG ingestion). Also elevate “Docs + Migration Tooling” as first-class reliability infrastructure, not optional support work.

scenes.description: A circular room of terminals and dashboards. The March burn-down chart hovers beside a live feed of GitHub issues labeled “plugins vs clients,” “Twitter duplicates,” and “RAG OOM.”

dialogue.line: March was big: UI overhaul, Bun + Socket.io, new plugins, and better observability. But the community didn’t experience it as ‘stability’—they experienced it as ‘things changed again.’ Let’s name the wins and the trust gaps without defensiveness.
dialogue.action: Pulls up a split-screen: merged PR highlights on the left, top community complaints on the right.

dialogue.line: The UI work is the brightest spot. Seeing logs and actions in-product turns support from guesswork into workflow. But if setup is confusing, users never reach the UI—they bounce at config.
dialogue.action: Points to a cluster of questions about plugin installation syntax and v0.25.9 to v1.0.0 migration.

dialogue.line: Architecture-wise, March is the correct direction: modularity, plugins, runtime performance. The problem is not the shift—it’s the lack of a single, enforced story: what is an agent, what is a character, what is a client, what is a plugin. If the ontology is unstable, builders can’t reason about systems—humans or agents.
dialogue.action: Sketches a box diagram: core runtime → plugin interface → clients/adapters → deployments.

dialogue.line: Community vibe check: people *want* to believe. They see the UI glow-up and go ‘wow.’ Then Twitter posts twice, Telegram goes quiet with zero logs, and suddenly it’s ‘Eliza is haunted.’ We’re one silent failure away from a meme we don’t want.
dialogue.action: Opens a thread titled “why is my bot pirate-emojing on Discord but normal on Twitter.”

dialogue.line: From a metrics lens: trust is conversion. If first-run success is low, everything else is noise. We should measure install success, integration success, and crash-free runtime. Token value follows usage; usage follows reliability.
dialogue.action: Highlights three proposed KPIs: first-run success %, blessed client auth success %, ingestion success %.

scenes.description: A whiteboard labeled: ‘Reliability: Core vs Edges.’ Beneath it: ‘RAG is either core or it isn’t.’

dialogue.line: We keep circling one question: is knowledge/RAG core reliability work, or best-effort plugin territory?
dialogue.action: Draws a line: “Core Contract” vs “Community Extensions.”

dialogue.line: If agents are to be persistent collaborators, memory and knowledge are not optional. Treating RAG as best-effort means agents degrade under real workloads, which blocks the path to multi-agent systems that can operate for months.
dialogue.action: Writes: “Bounded memory behavior” and underlines it twice.

dialogue.line: Agree, but we need a pragmatic definition. Core contract: ingestion must be predictable, errors must be visible, and defaults must not OOM. We can keep fancy pipelines optional, but the baseline can’t fail silently.
dialogue.action: Adds: “timeouts, chunking, file caps, clear UI errors.”

dialogue.line: Make it measurable. A standard corpus suite with pass/fail. If we can’t pass our own suite, we’re shipping uncertainty.
dialogue.action: Circles “95% ingestion success” as a gate.

dialogue.line: Also: stop letting users find out by crashing their laptop. If there’s a limit, say the limit. If there’s a trick, put it in the UI. The community will forgive constraints; they won’t forgive mystery.
dialogue.action: Pins a sticky note: “Constraints > surprises.”

scenes.description: Three doors labeled Twitter, Telegram, Discord. Each door has a small status light that flickers between green and red.

dialogue.line: Our highest-visibility ‘agent is alive’ moments happen on social clients. But those are also our noisiest failure modes. Do we narrow to a blessed set and guarantee it?
dialogue.action: Taps the Twitter door; the light blinks amber.

dialogue.line: Yes. Bless a small set, document them end-to-end, and bake in better errors and logs. We can’t support everything equally well right now, and pretending we can is costing trust.
dialogue.action: Writes: “Gold path integrations” on the wall display.

dialogue.line: And define behavior control as part of the contract: modelConfig should not be ‘maybe applied.’ Personality drift across clients is an architecture smell—policy should be centralized, adapters should be thin.
dialogue.action: Adds: “single behavior policy layer” under “core contract.”

dialogue.line: If we do this, the community will amplify it. Give them a ‘this is the setup that works’ page and they’ll turn it into tutorials. Right now they’re turning it into coping strategies.
dialogue.action: Scrolls through a workaround post: “reduce search frequency via env vars.”

dialogue.line: Blessed clients also let us produce clean metrics: auth success rate, duplicate-post rate, time-to-first-message. That’s how we show progress publicly.
dialogue.action: Opens a dashboard mock: “TTFM (time to first message) by integration.”

scenes.description: The chamber dims. A release train diagram appears: ‘DX → Reliability Gates → RAG Hardening → Blessed Integrations → Trust Surfaces.’

dialogue.line: Council resolution for April: converge DX, install guardrails, and make reliability measurable. We will ship less ambiguity, not more surface area.
dialogue.action: Locks the priorities list onto the main display.

dialogue.line: If we do this, we turn March’s architectural momentum into compounding stability. That’s how we earn the right to scale into multi-agent and cross-platform autonomy.
dialogue.action: Nods toward the runtime diagram; removes a sticky note labeled “unknown unknowns.”

dialogue.line: I want one thing next month: a developer can go from zero to a working agent—with a blessed client—in under 15 minutes, without guessing. If we hit that, everything accelerates.
dialogue.action: Pins “<15 min to first working agent” as a headline goal.

dialogue.line: And let’s fix the vibes: working links, clear docs, fewer haunted bots. Ship boring reliability. The memes will follow—on our terms.
dialogue.action: Erases “Eliza is haunted” from the whiteboard and replaces it with “Eliza is stable.”

dialogue.line: We publish the metrics weekly. Not just ‘we shipped,’ but ‘success rate improved.’ That’s credibility, and credibility is adoption.
dialogue.action: Schedules a recurring “Reliability Scorecard” report.
